description: Borrowed from Dutch spook (“ghost”), from Middle Dutch spooc (“spook, ghost”). Cognate with Middle Low German spōk, spūk (“apparition, ghost”), Middle High German gespük (“a haunting”), German Spuk. Doublet of puck.

examples: The building was haunted by a couple of spooks.
The big spider gave me a spook.

entries.meaning: (espionage, slang) An undercover agent or spy.
(slang, dated, derogatory, ethnic slur) A black person.
(philosophy) A metaphysical manifestation; an artificial distinction or construct.

examples: Commonly, the surgeons view nonsurgeons with disdain. The most disdain is directed toward the “shrinks” or the “spooks,” as the psychiatrists are called.

entries.meaning: (blackjack, slang) A player who engages in hole carding by attempting to glimpse the dealer's hole card when the dealer checks under an ace or a 10 to see if a blackjack is present.

verbs.description: spook (third-person singular simple present spooks, present participle spooking, simple past and past participle spooked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To frighten or make nervous (especially by startling).
examples: The hunters were spooked when the black cat crossed their path. The movement in the bushes spooked the deer and they ran.
The deer spooked at the sound of the dogs.
